Award.AwardTitle: Rigidity, Cohomology, and Approximate Embeddings in von Neumann Algebra Factors
Award.AbstractNarration:
The driving force behind many exciting developments in mathematics and its applications in recent years has been the dichotomy between structure (order, rigidity, etc.) and randomness (lack of structure, disorder, coarseness). This project concerns a powerful technique, called deformation-rigidity theory, to study these opposing phenomena in the framework of von Neumann algebras, i.e., algebras of infinite matrices, where the product of two elements, A times B, may be different from the product in reverse order, B times A, a fact that reflects the laws of quantum mechanics in particle physics (Heisenberg's Uncertainty Principle). Von Neumann algebras are also related to group theory and ergodic theory, since transformations of spaces give rise to a special class of such algebras called II1 factors. Rigidity in this context occurs when the group of transformations can be recognized by merely knowing its associated II1 factor (which is a very coarse object). The study of rigidity of factors is an interdisciplinary endeavor and can be relevant to many areas of mathematics. It also has applications to computer science, complexity theory, design computer networks, and the theory of error-correcting codes. This research project aims to deepen understanding in this important area.

The principal investigator recently added several new tools to this study, namely an approximation/simulation technique, a representation theory, and a cohomology. In this project, he intends to combine all these tools to further study rigidity-versus-randomness phenomena in II1 factors and to tackle several famous problems in this area: the Connes Approximate Embedding (CAE) conjecture, the sofic group problem, the free group factor problem, the paving problem, and calculations of invariants for group-like objects. It should be noted that the CAE conjecture, which predicts that II1 factors can be "simulated" on a computer, would have striking consequences in quantum information theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A striking feature of the PIs subject of Operator Algebras, and more specifically of the ``II1  factor framework'',  is its unique ability to host both rigidity  and randomness phenomena. This combination led the PI to many striking discoveries over the years, and to a fruitful interaction between operator algebras and other areas, such as group theory (measured, geometric, arithmetic, etc), quantum groups, random matrices, free probability, ergodic theory and descriptive set theory.  The PI developed several important techniques for studying II1 factors: finite dimensional approximation and reconstruction methods in subfactor theory, deformation rigidity theory, intertwining by bimodules, incremental patching, and more recently iterative embeddings with control of bimodule structure.   

In the last three years, the PI used a synthesis of these techniques to solve several long standing problems, some of which are ``final results'' in a certain direction. For instance, he proved that all cocycle actions of countable amenable groups can be perturbed by inner automorphisms to a genuine action. He also completely classified regular subalgebras of the hyperfinite II1 factor R, and proved that such factors embed ergodically into any other continuous factor. 

The PIs recent ideas and technique of iterative embeddings led him to propose a new approach towards proving the non-isomorphism of free group factors and their ``coarseness'',  a deep structural property  that generalizes many prior results and conjectures about these factors. This same technique also leads to a new approach to Connes approximate embedding conjecture and the sofic group problem,  and  it offers a new angle to  Connes bicentralizer  conjecture for III1 factors. The PIs deformation-rigidity theory allowed a spectacular progress in the  classification of II1 factors in recent years. The results he obtained  bridge to other areas of mathematics, leading to deep interdisciplinary activity and cross-pollination of several areas (operator algebra, group theory, orbit equivalence ergodic theory, logic), leading to substantial progress in each one of them.

The PIs continued his efforts do disseminate his ideas and techniques through Summer programs, mini-courses, his ``W*-News'' blog, his text book on II1 factors and his expository articles, as well as conferences, that he conducted and co-organized. His work continued to have impact in many areas, with a large number of research articles and PhD thesis directly sprouting from his work. He continued to recruit and train students and postdocs from under represented groups.
